feed.title: Combined summary - BIP 158 Flexibility and Filter Size

entry.title: Combined summary - BIP 158 Flexibility and Filter Size
entry.summary: Laolu Osuntokun submitted a pull request to modify BIP 158 in the Bitcoin Improvement Proposals (BIP) repository based on feedback and recent threads. He updated the test vectors and changed the use of prev output script instead of outpoints. However, modifying filters in this way could be a downgrade in the security model for light clients, as it allows full nodes to lie by omission. The discussion on the bitcoin-dev mailing list revolves around the possibility of letting full-nodes decide which subsets of elements it serves filters for, as opposed to deciding upfront which subset of elements will be most useful to include in the filters. There are concerns about the size of the filters making existing Simplified Payment Verification (SPV) clients less willing to adopt BIP 158 instead of the existing bloom filter garbage.The ongoing debate is between using a commitment structure or prev out scripts to reduce the size of filters. One argument against committing the filter is that it would require a soft fork, while using prev out scripts would not. However, the prev out script method has its own drawbacks, such as requiring mining template code to stuff blocks with spendable outputs, managing private keys and downstream software not tinkering with transaction count. Ultimately, the debate concerns optimizing for lower bandwidth or better security, and both methods have their trade-offs.Other proposed ideas include excluding all OP_RETURN outputs from BIP-158 filters for all transactions. The current filter format cannot be committed due to the circular dependency created by the indexing of each of the coinbase output scripts. The BIP157 protocol requires each filter to commit to the previous block's filter which validates the commitment at the tip of the chain. The security model is "at least one of my peers is honest."The discussions highlight ongoing efforts to optimize the Bitcoin network, while acknowledging that there are trade-offs and challenges involved in doing so. The aim is to minimize the bandwidth required to download each filter plus the expected bandwidth from downloading "large-ish" full segwit blocks.In conclusion, while BIP 158 offers many advantages over BIP 37, many existing mobile wallets that utilize BIP 37 lag massively behind the existing set of wallet related protocol upgrades and have not released versions of their applications that take advantage of segwit in any manner. The ongoing discussion revolves around proposals for reducing the size of Bitcoin's filters, including providing filters for certain script templates and deciding what data the filter should contain. The current debate is centered around the possibility of using input prevouts filter based on the scriptpubkey being spent.
